sen.j: 石清水八幡宮（いわしみずはちまんぐう）は京都府八幡市の男山山上にある神社である。
sen.e: Iwashimizu- Hachimangu Shrine is a Shrine located on top of Mt. Otokoyama in Yawata City, Kyoto.
Iwashimizu- Hachimangu Shrine is a Shrine located on top of Mt. Otokoyama in Yawata City, Kyoto.
Iwashimizu- Hachimangu Shrine is a Shrine located on top of Mt. Otokoyama in Yawata City, Kyoto.

sen.j: 宇佐神宮などとともに日本三大八幡宮のひとつに数えられる。
sen.e: It is considered one of three great Hachimangu Shrine in Japan along with Usa Jingu Shrine.
sen.cmt: Ise Jingu Shrine としました。
sen.e: It is considered one of three great Hachimangu Shrines in Japan along with Usa Jingu Shrine, etc.
sen.cmt: 3大なので、Shrine を複数に。など、で etc.を加えた。
sen.e: It is considered one of three great Hachimangu Shrines in Japan along with Usa Jingu Shrine, etc.

sen.j: 二十二社の上七社の一つであり、旧社格は官幣大社。
sen.e: This Shrine is in one of seven on the upper part of the mountain out of a total of twenty two shrines and in the old days was considered a Kanpei Taisha.
This Shrine is in one of the Upper Seven Shrines of the Twenty-Two Shrines and in the old days was considered a Kanpei Taisha.
sen.cmt: 左の定訳に沿った。Mountains は削除。
sen.e: This Shrine is in one of the Upper Seven Shrines of the Twenty-Two Shrines and in the old days was considered a Kanpei Taisha.

sen.j: 本殿など建造物9棟が国の重要文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: The main shrine and other 9 shrines are stated as important cultural property in Japan.
9 structures including the main shrine are designated as important cultural property in Japan.
sen.cmt: 建造物なのでShrine structureにした。など、なので本殿を含めて9棟。
sen.e: 9 structures including the main shrine are designated as important cultural property in Japan.

sen.j: また、本社は伊勢神宮に次ぐ国家第二の宗廟とされている。
sen.e: This Shrine is also considered as second national sobyo (Mausoleum) after Ise Jingu Shrine.
sen.cmt: 伊勢神宮→Ise Jingu、宗廟→sobyo （Mausoleum)を追加しました。
sen.e: This Shrine is also considered as second national sobyo (Mausoleum) after Ise Jingu Shrine.
This Shrine is also considered as second national sobyo (Mausoleum) after Ise Jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 祭神
sen.e: Respective gods
Deity of the Shrine
Deity of the Shrine

sen.j: 以下の三神を祀り、「八幡神」と総称する。
sen.e: The following three gods are called "Hachiman-shin"
The following three gods are enshrined and are collectively called "Hachiman-shin"
sen.cmt: 祀り、と 総称を加えた。
sen.e: The following three gods are enshrined and are collectively called "Hachiman-shin"

sen.j: 中御前 - 誉田別命（ほんだわけのみこと・第15代応神天皇）
sen.e: 1. Naka no gozen - Hondawake-no- mikoto (The 15th Emperor Ojin)
1. Naka no gozen - Hondawake-no- mikoto (The 15th Emperor Ojin)
1. Naka no gozen - Hondawake-no- mikoto (The 15th Emperor Ojin)

sen.j: 西御前 - 比売神（ひめおおかみ・宗像三女神）
sen.e: 2. Nishi no gozen (Hime-no-kami, Munakata Sanjojin)
2. Nishi no gozen (Hime-no-kami, Munakata Sanjojin)
2. Nishi no gozen (Hime-no-kami, Munakata Sanjojin)

sen.j: 東御前 - 息長帯姫命（おきながたらしひめのみこと・神功皇后）
sen.e: 3. Higashi no gozen - Okinagatarashi-hime-no-mikoto (Empress Jingu)
3. Higashi no gozen - Okinagatarashi-hime-no-mikoto (Empress Jingu)
3. Higashi no gozen - Okinagatarashi-hime-no-mikoto (Empress Jingu)

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 清和天皇が即位した翌年の貞観 (日本)元年（859年）の夏、弘法大師空海の弟子であった南都大安寺の僧行教が宇佐神宮に参詣した折に「われ都近く男山の峰に移座し国家を鎮護せん」との神託を受けた。
sen.e: It was in the summer of 859 AD (Jogan 1), one year after Emperor Seiwa came to power, when a monk named Gyokyo from Nanto Daianji Temple, a disciple of Kobo-Daishi Kukai visited Usa Jungu Shrine and received messages from Gods informing him to move the spirit inhabiting there, near Kyoto City, on the top of Mt. Otokoyama to help govern the nation.

It was in the summer of 859, one year after Emperor Seiwa came to power, when a monk named Gyokyo from Nanto Daianji Temple, a disciple of Kobo-Daishi Kukai visited Usa Jungu Shrine and received a message from God informing him to move the God to near Kyoto City, on the top of Mt. Otokoyama, to guard the nation.
sen.cmt: 元号を除く。神託を単数に。鎮護はgovernでなく guard に。
sen.e: It was in the summer of 859, one year after Emperor Seiwa came to power, when a monk named Gyokyo from Nanto Daianji Temple, a disciple of Kobo-Daishi Kukai visited Usa Jungu Shrine and received a message from God informing him to move the God to near Kyoto City, on the top of Mt. Otokoyama, to guard the nation.

sen.j: これを受けて、その翌年の860年、清和天皇の命により社殿を建立したのを創建とする。
sen.e: In 860 AD after Gyokyo received the message from the Gods, Emperor Seiwa ordered construction to start on the Iwashimizu Hachiman Shrine.

In 860, the year following the year that Gyokyo received this message from God, Emperor Seiwa ordered construction of the building of the Shrine, which is considered to be the start of the Iwashimizu Hachiman Shrine.
sen.cmt: ADを除く。翌年を加える。社殿、創建の意味を文字どおりに。
sen.e: In 860, the year following the year that Gyokyo received this message from God, Emperor Seiwa ordered construction of the building of the Shrine, which is considered to be the start of the Iwashimizu Hachiman Shrine.

sen.j: 「石清水」の社名は、もともと男山に鎮座していた石清水社（現在は石清水八幡宮の摂社）に由来する。
sen.e: The original spirit in Otokoyama was called Iwashimizu-sha, this is how the shrine got its name, the shrine is now called Sessha in Iwashimizu Hachimangu Temple.
Name of the Shrine, "Iwashimuzu", is taken from Iwashimizu-sha (now a Sessha of Iwashimizu Hachimangu Temple), which used to be located on Mt. Otokoyama.
sen.cmt: 原文どおりに修正しました。
sen.e: Name of the Shrine, "Iwashimizu," is taken from Iwashimizu-sha (now a Sessha of Iwashimizu Hachimangu Temple), which used to be located on Mt. Otokoyama.

sen.j: 以来、京都の北東にある比叡山延暦寺と対峙して京都の南西の裏鬼門を守護する王城守護の神、王権・水運の神として皇室・朝廷より篤い信仰を受け、天皇・上皇・法皇などの行幸啓は250余を数える。
sen.e: The Shrine is located on south west of Kyoto and protects the city from any bad spirits from this direction, while Mt.Hiei Enryakuji Temple is situated on the north east of Kyoto and performs the same role. The spirits in the shrine are considered protectors of the city and numerous emperors, retired emperors and monk emperors, more that two hundred and fifty, have come to the shrine to pray that they may get power from the spirits to make them successful and provide water for crops and protect from storms as well as them being protected from any bad luck.

From then on, the Shrine has been devotedly worshiped by the imperial family/imperial court, as the god protecting the imperial palace, the god of royal powers/water transport, that protect Urakimon located at south west of Kyoto, facing Mt. Hiei Enryaku-ji Temple, and visits by Emperors/ Retired Emperors/Monk Emperors to the Shrine amount to more than 250.
sen.cmt: 原文どおりに、かなり直しました。
sen.e: From then on, the Shrine has been devotedly worshiped by the imperial family/imperial court, as the god protecting the imperial palace, the god of royal powers/water transport, that protect Urakimon located at south west of Kyoto, facing Mt. Hiei Enryaku-ji Temple, and visits by Emperors/ Retired Emperors/Monk Emperors to the Shrine amount to more than 250.

sen.j: また、源氏をはじめ、足利氏・徳川氏・今川氏・武田氏など、多くの清和源氏の中の河内源氏の系統が氏神として信仰したことから武神・弓矢の神・必勝の神として崇敬された
sen.e: This Shrine is also considered to house the god of fighting, archery and victory and many Kawachi Genji family from Seiwa Genji such as the Ashikaga, Tokugawa, Imagawa, and Takeda clan take it as their guardian spirit.

This Shrine was also worshiped as guardian deity by Genji, as well as by many Kawachi Genji families among Seiwa Genji, such as the Ashikaga, Tokugawa, Imagawa, and Takeda clans, and was thus respected as the god of fighting, archery and victory.
sen.cmt: 氏神を guardian deity に。文章の順番を原文に沿って入れ替えた。
sen.e: This Shrine was also worshiped as guardian deity by Genji, as well as by many Kawachi Genji families among Seiwa Genji, such as the Ashikaga, Tokugawa, Imagawa, and Takeda clans, and was thus respected as the god of fighting, archery and victory.

sen.j: 当社の御神前で7歳の春に元服して「八幡太郎」と称した源義家の父の源頼義が、河内源氏の氏神とした壺井八幡宮は、石清水八幡宮を源氏の本拠地の河内国石川郡壷井(大阪府羽曳野市壺井)に勧請したもの。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi, father of MINAMOTO no Yoshiie underwent the Genpuku ceremony at the age of seven in Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine and was renamed Hachimantaro, he believed Tsuboihachimangu to be the god of the KawachiGenji clan and subsequently this god was moved from Iwashimizu Hachimangu to Tsuboi, Ishikawa district in the Kawachi Province where Genji's home town lay (Currently know as Tsuboi, Habikino-shi, Osaka)

MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi, father of MINAMOTO no Yoshiie underwent the Genpuku ceremony at the age of seven in Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine and was renamed Hachimantaro, and Tsuboi Hachimangu Shrine, which was made the guardian deity of the Kawachi Genji clan by him, was separated from Iwashimizu Hachimangu and moved to to Tsuboi, Ishikawa district in the Kawachi Province (currently Tsuboi, Habikino City, Osaka) which was the headquarters of the Genji clan.
sen.cmt: 氏神とした、勧請した、を修正/加えた。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi, father of MINAMOTO no Yoshiie underwent the Genpuku ceremony at the age of seven in Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine and was renamed Hachimantaro, and Tsuboi Hachimangu Shrine, which was made the guardian deity of the Kawachi Genji clan by him, was separated from Iwashimizu Hachimangu and moved to to Tsuboi, Ishikawa district in the Kawachi Province (currently Tsuboi, Habikino City, Osaka) which was the headquarters of the Genji clan.

sen.j: また鎌倉の鶴岡八幡宮は、源頼義が石清水八幡宮（あるいは壺井八幡宮）を勧請した鶴岡若宮にあり、源頼朝が幕府を開く際、鶴岡若宮を現在地に移し改めて石清水八幡宮を勧請したことを創始とする。
sen.e: MINAMOTONO no Yoriyoshi moved the god from Iwashimizu Hachimangu (also known as Tsuboi Hachimangu) to Tsurugaoka Hachimangu, Tsurugaoka Wakamiya in Kamakura City, when MINAMOTO no Yoritomo started his shognate government he moved Tsurugaoka Wakamiya to current place and again moved the god of Iwashimizu Hachimangu into the new shrine.

Tsurugaoka Hachimangu Shrine of Kamakura is located in Tsurugaoka Wakamiya, which was separated and moved from Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine (or Tsuboi Hachimangu Shrine) by MINAMOTONO no Yoriyoshi, and was initiated when MINAMOTO no Yoritomo moved Tsurugaoka Wakamiya to its current location upon the start of his Shogunate.
sen.cmt: 文章の順番を原文に沿って入れ替えた。
sen.e: Tsurugaoka Hachimangu Shrine of Kamakura is located in Tsurugaoka Wakamiya, which was separated and moved from Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine (or Tsuboi Hachimangu Shrine) by MINAMOTONO no Yoriyoshi, and was initiated when MINAMOTO no Yoritomo moved Tsurugaoka Wakamiya to its current location upon the start of his Shogunate.

sen.j: 創建以来、幕末までは神仏習合の宮寺で石清水八幡宮護国寺と称し、東寺（教王護国寺）や清水寺、比叡山延暦寺、仁和寺、鹿苑寺（相国寺・金閣寺・銀閣寺）など、多くの寺院との歴史的関連が深い。
sen.e: Due to Shinbutu shugo, this shrine is deeply related to many temples like To-ji, Kyo-o-gokoku-ji, Kiyomizu Temple,Ninna Temple, Rokuon-ji Temple (Shokoku-ji Temple, Kinkakuji Temple, Ginkakuji-Temple) and was called Iwashimizu Hachimangu Gokokuji Temple since its completion untill the end of Shogunate period.

From its establishment completion untill the end of Tokugawa Shogunate period, the shrine was a shinto shrine of shinbutsu shugo and was called Iwashimizu Hachimangu Gokokuji Temple, and the shrine is deeply and historically related to many temples such as To-ji (Kyo-o-gokoku-ji), Kiyomizu Temple, Ninna Temple, Rokuon-ji Temple (Shokoku-ji Temple, Kinkaku-ji Temple, Ginkakuji-Temple).
sen.cmt: 幕末に、徳川を加えた。宮寺をShinto Shrine。
sen.e: From its establishment completion untill the end of Tokugawa Shogunate period, the shrine was a shinto shrine of shinbutsu shugo and was called Iwashimizu Hachimangu Gokokuji Temple, and the shrine is deeply and historically related to many temples such as To-ji (Kyo-o-gokoku-ji), Kiyomizu Temple, Ninna Temple, Rokuon-ji Temple (Shokoku-ji Temple, Kinkaku-ji Temple, Ginkakuji-Temple).

sen.j: また、河内源氏と競合相手と考えられている伊勢平氏もこの社を重んじており、平正盛が造営の功を上げたことや平清盛ら伊勢平氏の主だった人々が八幡宮の臨時際で舞人を演じたとする記録が残されている。
sen.e: Ise Heishi also respected this shrine who was the opposition of Kawachi Genji, there is a record of TAIRA no Masamori contributed to build the shrine, also TAIRA no Kiyomori and other Ise Heishi performed Maijin at Rinjisai festival of Hachimangu.

Ise Heishi, who are considered to be the opposition of Kawachi Genji, also respected this shrine, and there is a record of TAIRA no Masamori who contributed in building of the shrine, and there are also records of TAIRA no Kiyomori and other main members of Ise Heishi, who performed Maijin at Rinjisai festival of Hachimangu.
sen.cmt: 文章の順番を原文に沿って入れ替えた。主だった、を加えた。
sen.e: Ise Heishi, who are considered to be the opposition of Kawachi Genji, also respected this shrine, and there is a record of TAIRA no Masamori who contributed in building of the shrine, and there are also records of TAIRA no Kiyomori and other main members of Ise Heishi, who performed Maijin at Rinjisai festival of Hachimangu.

sen.j: 明治時代（1868年）の神仏分離までは護国寺や極楽寺、弁天堂を始め「男山48坊」と呼ばれる数多くの宿坊が参道に軒を連ね、寛永の三筆として知られる松花堂昭乗も八幡大菩薩に仕える社僧の一人であった。
sen.e: There used to be many temples offering accommodation for pilgrimages and they were called "Otokoyama 48 bo" such as Gokokuji Temple, Gokurakuji Temple and Bentendo until Meiji government introduced Shinbutsu bunri in 1868 (Meiji period), Shojo SHOKADO was one of the monk served Hachimandai bosatsu, he was also known as one of the three best calligrapher in Kanei period.

Before Meiji Government introduced Shinbutsu bunri in 1868, many temples including Gokoku-ji Temple, Gokuraku-ji Temple and Bentendo, used to offer accommodation for pilgrimages and were called "Otokoyama 48 bo", and Shojo SHOKADO, who was one of the monks serving Hachiman Daibosatsu, was also known as one of the three best calligraphers in Kanei period.
sen.cmt: 文章を入れ替え、語数を減らした。
sen.e: Before Meiji Government introduced Shinbutsu bunri in 1868, many temples including Gokoku-ji Temple, Gokuraku-ji Temple and Bentendo, used to offer accommodation for pilgrimages and were called "Otokoyama 48 bo," and Shojo SHOKADO, who was one of the monks serving Hachiman Daibosatsu, was also known as one of the three best calligraphers in Kanei period.

sen.j: 1868年（明治元年）、仏教的神号の八幡大菩薩（はちまんだいぼさつ）は明治政府によって禁止された。
sen.e: In 1868 (Meiji 1) Hachimandai Bosatsu was forbidden by the Meiji government because of its strong Buddhist influence.
In 1868, Hachiman Daibosatsu was forbidden by the Meiji government because of its strong Buddhist influence.
In 1868, Hachiman Daibosatsu was forbidden by the Meiji government because of its strong Buddhist influence.

sen.j: 石清水八幡宮や鶴岡八幡宮の放生会は中秋祭に改めさせられた。
sen.e: Hojoe of Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine and Tsurugaoka Hachimangu were changed to Chushusai.
Hojoe of Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine and Tsurugaoka Hachimangu were changed to Chushusai.
Hojoe of Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine and Tsurugaoka Hachimangu were changed to Chushusai.

sen.j: 1871年、官幣大社に列するとともに、社号を「男山八幡宮」に改名されるが、1918年には石清水八幡宮に復する。
sen.e: In 1871 the shrine became Kanpe Taisya and was renamed "Otokoyama Hachimangu " and was again changed to the Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine in 1918.
In 1871 the shrine became Kanpe Taisya and was renamed "Otokoyama Hachimangu " and resumed the name of Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine in 1918.
In 1871 the shrine became Kanpe Taisya and was renamed "Otokoyama Hachimangu " and resumed the name of Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine in 1918.

sen.j: また現代では、松下電器産業の創業者でもあり「経営の神様」とも称された松下幸之助が深く信仰したほか、厄除開運、必勝、商売繁盛、家内安全などの御利益を願って全国から参拝者が足を運ぶ。
sen.e: Many people come from within Japan to pray for good luck, victory, business success and a safe year for the family, including in recent years, the God of Business, Konosuke MATSUSHITA founder of Panasonic corporation who respected this Shrine deeply.

Many people come from all parts of Japan to pray for good luck, victory, business success and a safe year for the family, including in recent years, Konosuke MATSUSHITA, founder of Panasonic corporation and referred to as "the God of Business", who respected this Shrine deeply.
sen.cmt: 全国から、の意味をわかりやすく。称された、を加えた。
sen.e: Many people come from all parts of Japan to pray for good luck, victory, business success and a safe year for the family, including in recent years, Konosuke MATSUSHITA, founder of Panasonic corporation and referred to as "the God of Business," who respected this Shrine deeply.

sen.j: 祭事
sen.e: Festivals
Festivals
Festivals

sen.j: 9月15日 - 石清水祭、放生会（葵祭・春日祭とともに日本三大勅祭のひとつ）
sen.e: The Iwashimizu Festival, Hojoe (one of Japanese three major Chokusai along with the Aoi Festival and the Kasuga Festival) are being held on 15th September.
The Iwashimizu Festival, Hojoe (one of Japanese three major Chokusai along with the Aoi Festival and the Kasuga Festival) are held on 15th September.
The Iwashimizu Festival, Hojoe (one of Japanese three major Chokusai along with the Aoi Festival and the Kasuga Festival) are held on 15th September.

sen.j: 境内外社
sen.e: Shrines outside Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine
Shrines inside/outside Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine
sen.cmt: 内外なので inside も加えた。
sen.e: Shrines inside/outside Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine

sen.j: 高良神社、相槌神社、石清水社、大扉稲荷社、三女神社、水分社、広田社、生田社、長田社、住吉社、一童社、龍田社、貴船社、若宮社、若宮殿社、気比社、水若宮社など
sen.e: Kora Shrine, Aizuchi Shrine, Iwashimizusha, Otobira inarisha, Sanmyo Shrine, Mikumarisha, Hirotasha, Ikutasha, Nagatasha, Sumiyoshisha, Ichidosha, Tatsutasha, Kibunesha, Wakamiyasha, Wakamiyadensha, Kehisha, Mizuwakamiyasha and so on.

Kora Shrine, Aizuchi Shrine, Iwashimizusha, Otobira inarisha, Sanmyo Shrine, Mikumarisha, Hirotasha, Ikutasha, Nagatasha, Sumiyoshisha, Ichidosha, Tatsutasha, Kibunesha, Wakamiyasha, Wakamiyadensha, Kehisha, Mizuwakamiyasha and so on.

Kora Shrine, Aizuchi Shrine, Iwashimizusha, Otobira inarisha, Sanmyo Shrine, Mikumarisha, Hirotasha, Ikutasha, Nagatasha, Sumiyoshisha, Ichidosha, Tatsutasha, Kibunesha, Wakamiyasha, Wakamiyadensha, Kehisha, Mizuwakamiyasha and so on.

sen.j: 付属施設 青雲寮、レストラン石翠亭、トーマス・エジソン記念碑、鳩嶺茶園、 青少年文化体育研修センター（楠峯館（宿泊）、鳩峯庵（茶室）、清峯殿（式場・会議室・宴会場）など
sen.e: Other facilities Seiunryo, Restaurant Sekisuitei, Monument of Thomas Edison, Kyurei tea room, Youth orientated cultural and physical education centre (Nampokan-accommodation), Kyuhoan (tea room), Seihoden (function room, meeting room, bar) and so on.
sen.cmt: 鳩嶺茶園→Kyureichaenを、Kyurei tea roomとしました。
sen.e: Other facilities Seiunryo, Restaurant Sekisuitei, Monument of Thomas Edison, Kyurei tea room, Youth orientated cultural and physical education centre (Nampokan(accommodation), Kyuhoan (tea room), Seihoden (function room, meeting room, bar) and so on).
sen.cmt: 文化研修センターの後のかっこのくくりが原文も少しおかしい。最後の「など」までが含まれると思う。宿泊は原文どおり、かっこでくくった。
sen.e: Other facilities Seiunryo, Restaurant Sekisuitei, Monument of Thomas Edison, Kyurei tea room, Youth orientated cultural and physical education centre (Nampokan accommodation), Kyuhoan (tea room), Seihoden (function room, meeting room, bar) and so on).

sen.j: 重要文化財「石清水八幡宮 幣殿及び舞殿」

Important cultural property "Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine East gate"

tit.j: 石清水八幡宮が登場する作品

sen.j: 徒然草第52段「仁和寺にある法師」
sen.e: Tsurezuregusa essay No. 52 "A monk at Ninnaji"
Tsurezuregusa essay No. 52 "A monk at Ninnaji Temple"
Tsurezuregusa essay No. 52 "A monk at Ninnaji Temple"

sen.j: 仁和寺に居た老僧は「一生に一度は石清水八幡宮へ行きたい」と思っていた。
sen.e: An old monk at Ninnaji Temple wanted to visit Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine once in his life time.
An old monk at Ninnaji Temple wanted to visit Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine once in his life time.
An old monk at Ninnaji Temple wanted to visit Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine once in his life time.

sen.j: 念願叶って石清水八幡宮へ行ったのだが、麓にある高良社や極楽寺などだけを参拝して満足し、他の人が石清水に行こうとして山を登っていたのに、今いる寺社が石清水だと思い込んで山に登らなかったという話。
sen.e: One day his wish came true and he visited the shrine, however he only visited Kora Shrine and Gokurakuji Temple at the bottom of the mountain, not realizing that people were climbing up higher to get to Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine.

One day his wish came true and he visited the shrine, however he only visited Kora Shrine and Gokurakuji Temple at the bottom of the mountain, believing that they were Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine, not realizing that people were climbing up higher to get to Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine.
sen.cmt: 「今いる寺社が石清水だと思い込んで」を加えた。
sen.e: One day his wish came true and he visited the shrine, however he only visited Kora Shrine and Gokurakuji Temple at the bottom of the mountain, believing that they were Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine, not realizing that people were climbing up higher to get to Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine.

sen.j: 「どんな小さなことにも案内する人が必要である」という話であり、中学校で教えられることの多い文である。
sen.e: This story teaches that you need to have a proper guide to lead you to the right direction in your life and is often introduced to students in Junior High School.
This story teaches that you need to have a proper guide to lead you to the right direction, however small the matter is, and is often introduced to students in Junior High School.
sen.cmt: 「どんな小さなこと」を加えた。
sen.e: This story teaches that you need to have a proper guide to lead you to the right direction, however small the matter is, and is often introduced to students in Junior High School.

sen.j: この話は、石清水八幡宮の本殿が男山の山頂にあることや、麓の摂末社も相当に壮大な造りであることを知っていて、初めて理解できる逸話である。
sen.e: To appreciate this story, you may need to know that the main shrine of Iwashimizu Hachimangu shrine is on top of Mt. Otokoyama while the Setsumatsusha shrine is on the bottom of the mountain but whose size would make you believe it to be the shrine of Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine.

To appreciate this story, you may need to know that the main shrine of Iwashimizu Hachimangu shrine is on top of Mt. Otokoyama and the Setsumatsusha shrine at the bottom of the mountain is also of maginificent time..
sen.cmt: 最後の意訳の部分は不要。Otokoyamaの次は「、や」なのでwhile ではなく、andにした。
sen.e: To appreciate this story, you may need to know that the main shrine of Iwashimizu Hachimangu shrine is on top of Mt. Otokoyama and the Setsumatsusha shrine at the bottom of the mountain is also of magnificent time.

sen.j: 今昔物語集
sen.e: Konjaku Story Collection

sen.e: Konjaku Monogatarishu
sen.cmt: "Monogatarishu"の方が訳語としては一般的。
sen.e: Konjaku Monogatarishu

sen.j: 最寄駅 京阪八幡市駅より京阪鋼索線男山山上駅
sen.e: Train access - take a train from Keihan Yawata-shi station on Keihan Cable line, get off at Otokoyama yamanoue station.
Train access - take a train from Keihan Yawata-shi station on Keihan Cable line, get off at Otokoyama yamanoue station.
Train access - take a train from Keihan Yawata-shi station on Keihan Cable line, get off at Otokoyama yamanoue station.

sen.j: 駐車場 あり(但し、西側の住宅街を抜ける必要があり、かなり判りにくい）
sen.e: Parking available on the south side of the shrine, however it is not easy to spot as you need to go through a residential area.
Parking available (however it is not easy to spot as you need to go through a residential area at the west side).
sen.cmt: 南側ではなく、西側。原文どおりに。
sen.e: Parking available (however it is not easy to spot as you need to go through a residential area at the west side).
